comments: Sarah has a strong vision for the product and understands market trends well.
Her competitive analysis and market research are always thorough and insightful.
She thinks strategically about long-term product direction.
Good at identifying opportunities and potential product gaps.
Sarah is passionate about solving customer problems and advocates for user needs.
She conducts thorough user research and brings valuable customer insights.
Always references customer data when making product decisions.
Sarah is dedicated and puts in long hours to get things done.
She's very responsive to messages and emails, even outside work hours.
Shows strong commitment to the product's success.
Sarah frequently changes priorities without clear communication, causing confusion and wasted effort.
Doesn't involve engineering early enough in the planning process, leading to unrealistic timelines.
Often makes commitments to stakeholders without checking with the team first.
Communication style can be abrasive and dismissive of concerns raised by the team.
Sends conflicting messages to different stakeholders about priorities and timelines.
Doesn't listen well in meetings - often interrupts or talks over others.
Fails to provide context when requesting work, making it hard to understand the 'why'.
Rarely acknowledges team contributions or says thank you.
Sarah starts many initiatives but doesn't follow through to completion.
Requirements are often vague or incomplete, requiring multiple rounds of clarification.
Doesn't track or measure success of launched features - moves on to next thing too quickly.
Poor at managing dependencies and coordinating across teams.
Frequently misses deadlines for deliverables like PRDs and roadmap updates.
Doesn't maintain product documentation or keep it up to date.
Sarah can become defensive when receiving feedback or pushback on ideas.
Shows visible frustration in meetings when things don't go her way.
Has sent heated emails that created unnecessary conflict.
Takes disagreements personally rather than focusing on the issues.
Can be passive-aggressive when she doesn't get her way.

specific_incidents.description: During sprint planning, Sarah insisted on adding three new features mid-sprint without removing anything, despite engineering explaining capacity constraints. When the team pushed back, she escalated to the VP, creating tension.

Sarah committed to a customer that a feature would be ready by end of Q2 without consulting the engineering team. When informed it would take 6 weeks longer, she blamed engineering for 'moving too slowly' in a company-wide meeting.
After receiving feedback about unclear requirements, Sarah sent a lengthy email defending her approach and questioning the team's competence. This damaged trust and required manager intervention.
Sarah's market analysis for the new enterprise features was excellent and helped secure buy-in from leadership for a major strategic initiative.

manager_notes: Sarah has strong product instincts and strategic thinking abilities, but significant concerns about collaboration, communication, and emotional intelligence. Multiple team members have expressed frustration working with her. This feedback represents a critical development opportunity. Sarah needs to focus on: 1) Building trust through consistent, transparent communication, 2) Involving stakeholders earlier in decision-making, 3) Managing emotions and responding professionally to feedback, 4) Improving follow-through and execution. Without improvement in these areas, her effectiveness as a PM will be limited.
